conclusion: Problem involves a fire truck with an electromagnetic railgun launching projectiles to extinguish fires in high-rise buildings.
Details given: horizontal distance L = 60 m, muzzle velocity v0 = 50 m/s, launch angle θ = 53°, neglect air resistance and railgun height.
Objective is to find the height H above the ground where the projectile hits the building.
Visualize the situation: fire truck with railgun aimed at high-rise building, projectile launched at angle θ with initial velocity v0.
Model the problem as a projectile motion problem in two dimensions: horizontal and vertical.
Recall that horizontal and vertical components of motion can be treated separately; horizontal component is constant, vertical is affected by gravity.
Calculate horizontal component of initial velocity: vx = v0 cos θ.
Calculate vertical component of initial velocity: vy = v0 sin θ.
Find cos 53° using identity sin²θ + cos²θ = 1; cos 53° = 0.6.
Calculate vx = 50 × 0.6 = 30 m/s and vy = 50 × 0.8 = 40 m/s.
Find time t for projectile to travel horizontal distance L = 60 m with constant horizontal velocity 30 m/s: t = L / vx = 2 seconds.
Calculate vertical displacement y after time t using y = vy t - 1/2 g t².
Plug values into vertical displacement equation: y = 40 × 2 - 1/2 × 10 × 2² = 60 meters.
Determine height H above ground where projectile hits building is equal to vertical displacement y = 60 meters.
Consider alternative approach using range equation for projectile motion, but current method should suffice.
Reflect on using equations of motion in vertical direction.
Verify horizontal position at time t: x(t) = vx t = 60 m confirms t = 2 s.
Reconfirm vertical position at t = 2 s using y(t) = vy t - 1/2 g t² results in y = 60 m.
